title: Credit (creative arts)
text:
In general, the term credit in the artistic or intellectual sense refers to an acknowledgment of those who contributed to a work, whether through ideas or in a more direct sense.
Credit in the arts.
In the creative <a href="arts">arts</a>, credits are an acknowledgment of those who participated in the production. They are often shown at the end of movies and on CD jackets. In <a href="film">film</a>, <a href="video">video</a>, <a href="television">television</a>, <a href="theater">theater</a>, etc., "credits" means the list of <a href="actor">actor</a>s and behind-the-scenes staff who contributed to the production.
Non-fiction.
In <a href="non-fiction">non-fiction</a> writing, especially academic works, it is generally considered important to give credit to sources of information and ideas. Failure to do so often gives rise to charges of <a href="plagiarism">plagiarism</a>, and "piracy" of <a href="intellectual%20rights">intellectual rights</a> such as the right to receive a <a href="copyright">royalty</a> for having written. In this sense the financial and <a href="individual%20capital">individual</a> meanings are linked.
Academic papers generally contain a lengthy section of footnotes or <a href="scientific%20citation">citations</a>. Such detailed crediting of sources provides readers with an opportunity to discover more about the cited material. It also provides a check against misquotation, as it's easy for an attributed quote to be checked when the reference is available. All of this is thought to improve <a href="integrity">integrity</a> of the <a href="instructional%20capital">instructional capital</a> conveyed, which may be quite fragile, and easy to misinterpret or to misapply.
In fiction.
In <a href="fiction">fiction</a> writing, authors are generally expected to give credit to those who contributed significantly to a work. Sometimes authors who do not want credit for their work directly may choose to use a <a href="pen%20name">pen name</a>. A <a href="ghostwriter">ghostwriter</a> gives all or some of the credit for his or her writing to someone else.
In computing.
In <a href="computer%20software">computer software</a> <a href="software%20license">licenses</a>, attribution of credit is sometimes a condition of licensing. For example, original versions of the <a href="BSD%20license">BSD license</a> controversially required credit to be provided in the advertisement for software that used licensed code, but only if features or use of the licensed software was mentioned in the advertisement.
<a href="Software%20documentation">Software documentation</a> is sometimes licensed under similar terms. For example, the <a href="GNU%20Free%20Documentation%20License">GNU Free Documentation License</a> (GFDL) used by <a href="Wikipedia">Wikipedia</a> requires that acknowledgments to authors be preserved.
